name: Combinations
title: Combinations
content:
Given two integers n and k, return all possible combinations of k numbers chosen from the range [1, n].

You may return the answer in any order.

 

Example 1:

Input: n = 4, k = 2
Output: [[1,2],[1,3],[1,4],[2,3],[2,4],[3,4]]
Explanation: There are 4 choose 2 = 6 total combinations.
Note that combinations are unordered, i.e., [1,2] and [2,1] are considered to be the same combination.

Example 2:

Input: n = 1, k = 1
Output: [[1]]
Explanation: There is 1 choose 1 = 1 total combination.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= n <= 20
  • 1 <= k <= n

discussion_posts.name: nurlan01
discussion_posts.content: Guys, no solution needs to be published in this section, this section is for only discussion!!

discussion_posts.name: AlecLC
discussion_posts.content: Always encouraging to revisit problems you struggled with so hard before and now they're easy :)

discussion_posts.name: moraalejandro94
discussion_posts.content: If not familiar with backtracking it\'s definitely worth it to go over some simple examples of it. Then the problem becomes easy, otherwise it\'s pretty hard

discussion_posts.name: killua8p
discussion_posts.content:
If you are wondering why your Python solution is slower than 90% of users -- because most submissions have been using the builtin `itertools.combinations`. So your Backtracking / BFS based algorithm might still be pretty good despite what the result tells you.

What is wrong with `itertools.combinations`?
Nothing. In production, you will want to use it as it's blazing fast.
In interviews, you will want to avoid it as that's not what interviewers are looking for.

I got this error:

    Input:	2, 2
    Output:	[[2,1]]

I can easily flip the order and get OJ to accept, but why does the order matter?

discussion_posts.name: Mister_CK
discussion_posts.content: @Leetcode this is probably the easiest backtracking problem, so I would tag it as easy to signal that this is a good one to start with.

discussion_posts.name: anwendeng
discussion_posts.content:
Here I provide other idea from backtracking. I prefer to use DP.
Let's  solve it by Math. Consider the set 
$$ 
C_k^n=\{\{i_1,\cdots, i_k\}|1\leq i_1<\cdots< i_k\leq n\}
$$
then, it follows
$$
C_k^n=C_k^{n-1} \cup C_{with\ n}^n
$$
where
$$
C_{with\ n}^n=\{\{i_1,\cdots, i_k\}|1\leq i_1<\cdots<i_{k-1}< i_k= n\}
$$.
The crucial part is that there exists an one-to-one correspondence between the sets $C_{k-1}^{n-1}$ and $C_{with\ n}^n$ with
$$
v\in C_{k-1}^{n-1} \longrightarrow v\cup \{n \} \in C_{with\ n}^n.
$$

discussion_posts.content: A great problem to practice backtracking with!
